summary: Robert A. Maheu was a personnel relations executive and former FBI agent who was utilized by the CIA's Office of Security for sensitive assignments starting in the early 1950s. He had a diverse employment history, including time with the FBI, the Small Business Administration, and his own investigative organization, Robert A. Maheu Associates. He was recruited by the CIA in 1954 and became involved in sensitive operations, including the attempted assassination of Fidel Castro and providing companionship to King Hussein of Jordan. Maheu was also associated with the Hughes Tool Company, and his activities were investigated by International Intelligence, Inc. (INTERTEL) on behalf of Hughes. There was concern within the CIA regarding potential risks associated with Maheu due to Senate Subcommittee interest in his activities.
significance: The documents suggest that Robert A. Maheu was involved in sensitive and potentially controversial activities during the Cold War era, including a plot to assassinate Fidel Castro. While the documents do not directly link Maheu to the JFK assassination, his connections to the CIA and involvement in covert operations make him a person of interest in understanding the broader context of the time. The documents highlight the potential risks associated with his activities and the concerns within the CIA regarding scrutiny from Senate Subcommittees.
